title: 111_hr3550
content: The Act titled "Senior Investor Protections Enhancement Act of 2009" defines key terms. The "Senior Investor Protections Enhancement Act of 2009" defines key terms, including "senior" as an individual aged 62 or older and "securities laws" as specific acts related to securities regulation. The Act amends various sections to include the new definition of "senior." The Securities Exchange Act of 1934, Investment Company Act of 1940, and Investment Advisers Act of 1940 have been amended to define "senior" as an individual aged 62 or older. ENHANCED PENALTIES FOR VIOLATIONS OF SECURITIES ACT OF 1933. Enhanced penalties for violations of the Securities Act of 1933 include special rules for seniors, allowing the Commission to impose a civil penalty of up to $50,000 for each violation directed towards or committed against a senior. Special Rule for Seniors: If a violation of the Securities Act of 1933 is directed towards or committed against a senior, the Commission may impose a civil penalty of up to $50,000 for each violation. Enhanced penalties for violations of Securities Act of 1934. Enhanced penalties for violations of Securities Act of 1934 include a special rule for seniors, allowing the Commission to impose a civil penalty of up to $50,000 for each violation directed towards or committed against a senior. Willful violations also have a special rule for seniors, with enhanced penalties for acts or omissions targeting seniors. The Securities Act of 1934 is amended to include a special rule for seniors, allowing the Commission to impose a civil penalty of up to $50,000 for violations directed towards or committed against seniors. Enhanced penalties for violations of the Investment Company Act of 1940 are introduced. Enhanced penalties for violations of the Investment Company Act of 1940 are introduced, including a special rule for seniors where a civil penalty of up to $50,000 may be imposed for each violation directed towards or committed against a senior. The Investment Company Act of 1940 introduces enhanced penalties for violations, with a special rule for seniors allowing a civil penalty of up to $50,000 for each violation targeting or involving a senior. Enhanced penalties for violations of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 are introduced. Enhanced penalties for violations of the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 are introduced, including a special rule for seniors where civil penalties of up to $50,000 may be imposed for violations directed towards or committed against seniors. The Investment Advisers Act of 1940 introduces enhanced penalties for violations, with a special rule for seniors allowing civil penalties of up to $50,000 for violations targeting or involving seniors. Directive to the United States Sentencing Commission. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend the Federal sentencing guidelines to ensure appropriate punishment for violations of securities laws against seniors. This includes applying specific guidelines to offenses involving senior victims, maintaining consistency with other directives, making necessary changes to guidelines, and ensuring alignment with sentencing purposes. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend Federal sentencing guidelines to ensure they meet the purposes of sentencing for violations of securities laws against seniors.
